docs.lead_paragraph: The Fire Department and the union for city emergency medical technicians agreed yesterday to forestall the elimination of 75 ambulance shifts around the city, a cut that had been included in the city's plans to close its $4.76 billion deficit. The cuts were scheduled to be carried out on Sunday, for a saving of $3.3 million this year and $10 million next year, Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta said.

headline.main: Fire Dept. Postpones Plan to Cut E.M.S. Shifts

docs.abstract: New York City Fire Department and union for emergency medical technicians agree to postpone elimination of 75 ambulance shifts and look for other ways to address city's budget gap (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: JUST a few weeks ago it was all the rage, remember? The women's health care bill. Two of them, actually. In a rare case of Albany acting quickly, both chambers approved viable bills, trying to grab the advantage in the special State Senate election on Manhattan's East Side between Assemblyman John Ravitz, a Republican, and Liz Krueger, a Democrat. The election turned fierce because Republicans desperately wanted to hold on to the seat that Roy M. Goodman gave up after 33 years to join the new mayoral administration, while the Democrats aspired to pick off the district for themselves.

headline.main: Metro Matters; After Election, Health Bill Loses Allure

docs.abstract: Joyce Purnick bemoans lack of action on women's health care bill in New York, which was hot issue during campaign for vacant State Senate seat between Liz Krueger and John Ravitz; two legislative sides have retreated and bill appears to have stalled (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Bush Welcomes Saudi Plan For Peace in Middle East President Bush called Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia and praised his general proposal for Israel to withdraw completely from the West Bank and Gaza in return for full normalization of relations with all Arab countries. Palestinian officials have reacted favorably to the proposal, but Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon, has made no public comment. A1 Japan's Economic Plan Faulted Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's economic package got a tepid response from the market and analysts, who said they had been hoping for bolder measures. A3

docs.lead_paragraph: A 30-year-old woman who is very likely to develop a rare form of Alzheimer's disease before she turns 40 has had a baby girl who will be spared that fate because she was genetically screened as an embryo before being implanted in her mother's womb, doctors are reporting. The case is a medical milestone, the first use of genetic testing to prevent an early onset form of Alzheimer's disease. But some find it ethically disturbing because within a few years the mother will probably become unable to take care of her daughter, who will witness her deterioration and death.

headline.main: Baby Spared Mother's Fate By Genetic Tests as Embryo

docs.abstract: 30-year-old woman who is very likely to develop rare form of Alzheimer's disease before she turns 40 has had baby girl who will be spared that fate because she was genetically screened as embryo before being implanted in mother's womb; first such use of genetic testing, reported in AMA Journal, raises ethical questions, since woman will likely not be able to raise child; form of Alzheimer's she has accounts for less than one percent of all cases (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Pataki administration said today that it was planning to continue to spend heavily on advertising to promote tourism next year, drawing howls of protest from Gov. George E. Pataki's political opponents, who say the governor appears far too often in public service announcements. Testifying before a legislative committee, the governor's economic development commissioner, Charles A. Gargano, said the state intended to use about $20 million left over from an emergency appropriation after Sept. 11 to pay for advertising during the next fiscal year, beginning on April 1. That money will be added to its annual financing of $7.7 million.

headline.main: Rivals Are Angry That Pataki May Star in More Tourism Ads

docs.abstract: Pataki administration says that it is planning to continue to spend heavily on advertising to promote tourism next year, drawing howls of protest from Gov George E Pataki's political opponents, who say that Pataki appears far too often in public service announcements; Charles A Gargano, Pataki's economic development commissioner, says state intends to use about $20 million left over from emergency appropriation after Sept 11 to pay for advertising during next fiscal year, testimony before legislative committee (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: As labor leaders gather here, they are grumbling that many of the issues that American workers care deeply about -- issues like soaring health care costs and safeguarding Social Security -- are largely absent from the nation's political dialogue, eclipsed by the war on terrorism and the Republican push for tax cuts. So at the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s executive council meeting, they agreed today to try to shift the nation's focus to worker-related issues.

headline.main: Unions Hope to Regain Attention of Lawmakers

docs.abstract: As labor leaders gather in New Orleans, they grumble that many of issues that American workers care deeply about--issues like soaring health care costs and safeguarding Social Security--are largely absent from nation's political dialogue, eclipsed by war on terrorism and Republican push for tax cuts; at AFL-CIO's exec council meeting, they agree to try to shift nation's focus to worker-related issues; photo of AFL-CIO pres John J Sweeney (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With tattoo artists, blues bands and a motorcycle contest, the Hells Angels' Hellraiser Ball 2002 had a few simple goals: raising the legendary motorcycle club's profile on Long Island, and making a profit. But then dozens of bearded, denim-vested members of the rival Pagan Outlaw Motorcycle Club barged into the ball here at the Vanderbilt catering hall on Saturday, and everything went wrong. Not only was one of the intruders shot dead and a Hells Angel member charged with second-degree murder, but the weekend event backfired in other ways, too.

headline.main: Melee Hinders Hells Angels In Attempt to Improve Image

docs.abstract: Hells Angels' efforts to improve public image of motorcyclists on Long Island are set back by melee that erupts when dozens of members of rival Pagan Outlaw Motorcycle Club barge into Hellraiser Ball at catering hall in Plainview; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The nation's governors demanded today that Congress and President Bush take immediate action to slow the explosive growth of Medicaid, which they say has become unsustainable in its current form. Medicaid dominated discussions today at the winter meeting of the National Governors Association. State officials sounded a note of desperation as they sought ways to control health spending.

headline.main: Governors Say States Need More Federal Help to Deal With Rising Costs of Medicaid

docs.abstract: Medicaid dominates discussions at winter meeting of National Governors Assn; nation's governors demand that Congress and Pres Bush take immediate action to slow explosive growth of Medicaid, which they say has become unsustainable in its current form; governors advance numerous proposals to control Medicaid spending and plead with federal government for financial help; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A2-8 Israel Declines to Lift Restrictions on Arafat The Israeli government decided to keep Yasir Arafat restricted to the West Bank city of Ramallah, while loosening the military cordon at his compound. The Palestinians reacted angrily, canceling planned security talks and saying that the decision was meaningless since Mr. Arafat was already moving around Ramallah. A1 Colombia Conflict Worsens The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia kidnapped their second hostage in a week: Ingrid Betancourt, a presidential candidate and critic of the leftist guerrillas. Just a month ago, there were signs of new peace talks with the government, but now many Colombians fear an intensification of the 38-year civil war, and some say the rebels have only themselves to blame. A6

docs.lead_paragraph: Sydney De Haan, a British hotel owner whose idea for attracting out-of-season guests led him to create one of the first tour companies catering to retirees, died on Feb. 16 in Folkestone, Kent. He was 83. His company, Saga Holidays, which has offered low-cost, all-inclusive packages since its founding in 1951, is generally credited with discovering the spending power of older British travelers, even those on a tight budget.

headline.main: Sydney De Haan, 83, Creator Of the Budget Package Tour
